subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.
Boil water in a pot and add salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk and cheese mixture.
Stir quickly to combine, allowing the heat from the pasta to cook the egg yolks and create a creamy sauce. Add more pasta water if needed to achieve desired creaminess.
Finish with additional black pepper and grated pecorino or parmesan cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-1
outcome: Egg yolks separated and placed in a bowl
Grated pecorino romano cheese mixed with egg yolks
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl. Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Egg yolks are used in carbonara to create a creamy sauce. Pecorino Romano cheese adds flavor to the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick or the back and forth method to separate the yolks. If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-2
outcome: Bacon is cooked until crispy and cooled slightly.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooling the bacon slightly prevents overcooking the egg-based sauce when it is added later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Wait until there's no sizzle left and a bit longer to ensure the bacon is not too hot for the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-3
outcome: A creamy sauce is created by cooking the egg yolks with the heat from the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Stir quickly to combine the pasta with the sauce, allowing the heat from the pasta to cook the egg yolks and create a creamy sauce. Add more pasta water if needed to achieve desired creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the pasta cooks the egg yolks, creating a creamy sauce. Adding pasta water helps achieve the desired creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is not too hot to avoid overcooking the egg-based sauce. Add pasta water gradually to control the sauce's consistency.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.

So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon. subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-1
materials: half a pound of thick-cut bacon
outcome: Bacon is crispy and fat is rendered out
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces. Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional). Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Rendering out the fat from the bacon makes it crispy, which is desirable for the texture and flavor of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use thick-cut bacon for better texture. Olive oil is optional and not traditional, but can be used if desired.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Pasta water is seasoned with salt
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Usually, more salt is added, but because there are many salty elements in carbonara, less salt is used in the pasta water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcome: Grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese
Egg and cheese mixture with black pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese. In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture. Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The cheese and egg mixture forms the base of the carbonara sauce, which will coat the pasta. The black pepper adds flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a fine grater for the cheese to ensure it mixes well with the eggs. Adjust the amount of black pepper to your taste preference.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-1
outcome: Bacon is crispy and some is set aside for garnish.
Most of the bacon fat is drained, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.

subgoal_summaries.explanation: This step is important to ensure that the bacon is crispy for garnish and to control the amount of fat used in the pasta, which affects the texture and flavor of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Use a paper towel to drain the bacon for garnish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-5
outcome: Spaghetti is transferred to the pan with bacon.
Egg and cheese mixture coats the spaghetti, creating a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs. If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The eggs are going to cook from the heat of the pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be gentle with the pasta to avoid breaking it. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it up and help establish a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-6
outcome: Pasta is plated with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon on top.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Go ahead and plate this up. Just get it off the tongs like so. Now to finish a little more Parmigiano Reggiano all over, and of course, some of your crispy bacon.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more cheese and crispy bacon on top enhances the flavor and texture, providing a creamy and crunchy contrast.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is plated neatly and evenly distribute the cheese and bacon for the best presentation and taste.

steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta and place it into the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook for 8 minutes.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm slices, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorn.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, including some pasta water, to stop frying and start emulsifying.
Toss the pasta in the pan with the guanciale fat and pasta water to create a creamy sauce.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Adjust the sauce consistency by adding more pasta water if needed.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.

Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.

subgoals.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
subgoals.text: Then there's the black pepper. Get your peppercorns in a pestle and mortar. Crack it. Get a little sieve. This is one of the most important little bits and no one really does it, okay. Honestly, this is the outer skin. This is much milder. What we have here is the inside part, the peppercorn, which is hotter. Perfect for a good hot carbonara.
original_steps: Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorn.

subgoals.title: Prepare Meat-5
subgoals.text: The guanciale is getting golden.
original_steps: Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.

subgoals.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-6
subgoals.text: Now, let's get on to the eggs. Eggs are really, really delicate and if you don't treat these right, you end up with stirfried noodles and we don't want that. I'm gonna take a bowl and I'm gonna crack the egg straight into there and I'm just gonna add a little pecorino to that. So, like 20 grams.
original_steps: Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.

subgoals.title: Prepare Meat-7
subgoals.text: Now, we're time sensitive so we're gonna have a little whisk up. We've got dark guanciale. We've got the fat that's come out of it and that's what you want. You want attitude and colour. Now, I'm gonna remove that garlic.
original_steps: Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.

subgoals.title: Combine Ingredients-8
subgoals.text: Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan. Use the water to stop the frying. Bit of water, bit of water. That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce. We're not frying anymore. Can you hear that? Quiet. No frying at all. Only then can we think about adding our egg. As we toss, we add some more liquid. That's the cream. You get the cream through the emulsification of the cooking water and the fat and technique and timing. So, as simple as this is, it's technical. Get your friends, your family, get them around the table. Glass of wine. Look at that guys, look at that.
original_steps: Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, including some pasta water, to stop frying and start emulsifying.
Toss the pasta in the pan with the guanciale fat and pasta water to create a creamy sauce.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Adjust the sauce consistency by adding more pasta water if needed.

subgoals.title: Garnish and Serve-9
subgoals.text: Carbonara and you finish with more pepper. I'm so excited. Spaghetti, carbonara with a beautiful little finishing of pecorino. That is as classic as I can give you guys. From chefs, from nonnas. It's about quality ingredients, the guanciale, the pecorino romana, quality eggs, the pepper, the technique of the pepper, good pasta and then the sensitivity of cooking it right. Come on. There's a little platter for two people and of course the most important thing when you eat pasta is don't watch it, eat it. Mmm, that my friends is a thing of joy.
original_steps: Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Gather Ingredients-1
outcome: Ingredients are gathered and ready for making Pasta Carbonara
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: These are the essential ingredients needed to make an authentic Pasta Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get guanciale with the fat not cut off, as you need it for the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Pasta is cooked and not sticking together
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grab the pasta by two hands, twist it into the boiling water, and cook for eight minutes.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Twisting the pasta prevents it from sticking together. A tiny amount of salt is added because the cheese and guanciale are already salty.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a tiny amount of salt in the water to avoid over-salting the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
outcome: Guanciale is sliced into 1 cm slices and chopped into 0.5 cm chunks
Guanciale is cooked and its fat is rendered
Garlic flavor is infused into the guanciale
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm slices, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat. Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pan is started cold to render the fat out of the guanciale. The garlic is added to infuse its perfume into the fat as it renders.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before adding the guanciale to properly render the fat.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
outcome: Hotter inner part of the peppercorn is separated and ready to use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack the black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift them to separate the hotter inner part from the milder outer skin.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The inner part of the peppercorn is hotter and perfect for a good hot carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: This is an important step that many people overlook, as the outer skin is much milder.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
materials: Guanciale, which is the cured cheek of pork, golden and crispy
Garlic clove, used to infuse flavor
outcome: Garlic is removed from the pan, leaving behind the infused flavor in the guanciale fat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The garlic is removed after the guanciale is golden to ensure it has infused its flavor into the fat without burning.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the garlic is only cracked and not chopped, to allow easy removal and prevent it from burning.
tools: Pan, used to cook the guanciale and garlic

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
outcome: Egg and cheese mixture
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack the egg into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk them together.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid ending up with stir-fried noodles instead of a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
outcome: Garlic is removed from the pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Remove the garlic from the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The garlic has infused its flavor into the fat, and now it is removed to prevent it from overpowering the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is golden before removing the garlic to maximize flavor extraction.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-8
outcome: Pasta is mixed with guanciale fat and pasta water to create a creamy sauce
Egg and cheese mixture is incorporated into the pasta without scrambling
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, including some pasta water, to stop frying and start emulsifying. Toss the pasta in the pan with the guanciale fat and pasta water to create a creamy sauce. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs. Adjust the sauce consistency by adding more pasta water if needed.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water and guanciale fat emulsify to create a creamy sauce. Turning off the heat and adding pasta water stops the frying process, allowing for emulsification. Tossing quickly with the egg mixture prevents the eggs from scrambling.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Toss quickly to incorporate the egg and cheese mixture smoothly.

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-9
outcome: Pasta carbonara is finished with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the pasta carbonara by adding more cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more pepper and cheese enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, making it more authentic and delicious.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pepper is freshly cracked for the best flavor, and use high-quality pecorino romano cheese for authenticity.

steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
In a bowl, beat two egg yolks for the sauce.
Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix well.
Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir the pasta until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta evenly.
Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-1
outcome: Spaghettoni is cooked and ready for the next step
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter. Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Salt is added to the water to enhance the flavor of the pasta. Stirring prevents the pasta from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the water is boiling before adding the pasta. Do not add oil to the water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-2
outcome: Guanciale chunks
Cooked guanciale with released fat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks. Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The guanciale is cooked to release its fat, which forms the base of the sauce for Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Cut the guanciale into big chunks. If you don't want too much fat, you can absorb some of it with a paper towel after cooking.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcome: A mixture of beaten egg yolks, cheese, and pepper for the sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks. Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix well.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The mixture of egg yolks, cheese, and pepper forms the base of the sauce for Carbonara, providing creaminess and flavor without the use of cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add cream to the mixture, as it is not part of the traditional Carbonara recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-4
outcome: Pasta is mixed with guanciale and egg mixture without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly. Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta should not be too hot when mixed with the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling, allowing them to coat the pasta properly.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is not too hot before adding the pasta to prevent the eggs from scrambling.

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-5
outcome: Pasta Carbonara is decorated with additional cheese and pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Serve the pasta with additional grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and a touch of pepper for decoration.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: This step is for decoration and to enhance the flavor of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Choose between parmesan or pecorino based on your preference.

subgoal_definitions.title: Gather Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Collect all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including bacon or guanciale, cheese, eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
original_steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Meat
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop the bacon or guanciale into small pieces and cook until crispy, optionally adding garlic for flavor.
original_steps: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm slices, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Grate the cheese and mix it with eggs and black pepper to create the egg mixture.
original_steps: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks for the sauce.
Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper to the egg yolks and mix well.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorn.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk together.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil salted water and cook the pasta until it is al dente, reserving some pasta water for later use.
original_steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta and place it into the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook for 8 minutes.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot and add salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix the cooked pasta with the meat in the pan, then add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce. Adjust the consistency with reserved pasta water if needed.
original_steps: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir the pasta until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta evenly.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale pan and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot, including some pasta water, to stop frying and start emulsifying.
Toss the pasta in the pan with the guanciale fat and pasta water to create a creamy sauce.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing quickly to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Adjust the sauce consistency by adding more pasta water if needed.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to avoid scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk and cheese mixture.
Stir quickly to combine, allowing the heat from the pasta to cook the egg yolks and create a creamy sauce. Add more pasta water if needed to achieve desired creaminess.

subgoal_definitions.title: Garnish and Serve
subgoal_definitions.description: Add additional cheese and black pepper as garnish before serving the Pasta Carbonara.
original_steps: Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.
Finish with additional black pepper and grated pecorino or parmesan cheese before serving.
